The Power of the Right Routine

According to researchers at Duke University, nearly 40 percent of our choices are deeply unconscious.  

We don’t think about them in the usual sense.  

There is both danger and opportunity in this.  

The opportunity is that we can develop new abilities.  

These abilities eventually become instinctive.  

The danger is that we may develop counterproductive routines.  

Without being fully aware, we can get caught in nonessential habits.  

We might check our email the second we get out of bed.  

We might pick up a doughnut on the way home from work.  

We might spend our lunch hour trolling the Internet.  

Instead, we should use that time to think, reflect, recharge, or connect.  

How can we discard routines that keep us locked in nonessential habits?  

How can we replace them with routines that make executing essentials effortless?  

OVERHAUL YOUR TRIGGERS  

Most of us have a behavioral habit we want to change.  

This could be eating less junk food, wasting less time, or worrying less.  

But when we try, changing even the simplest habit is hard.  

It feels like a gravitational force pulls us back to those habits.  

This includes French fries, goofy cat websites, or spirals of worry.  

How do we resist the powerful pull of these habits?  

In an interview about his book, The Power of Habit, Charles Duhigg said:  

“In the last 15 years, we’ve learned how habits work and how they can be changed.”  

Scientists have explained that every habit is made up of three parts.  

These parts are a cue, a routine, and a reward.  

The cue is a trigger that tells your brain to go into automatic mode.  

It also tells which habit to use.  

Then there is the routine, which is the behavior itself.  

This behavior can be physical, mental, or emotional.  

Finally, there is a reward.  

The reward helps your brain figure out if the habit is worth remembering.  

Over time, this loop becomes more automatic.  

The cue and reward become neurologically intertwined.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Our unconscious choices can lead to both unproductive routines and the opportunity to develop new, instinctive abilities.
